reasoning: The critique targets a real pillar of the essay’s case: that on linear/unbounded (and many practically-linear) value views, scale dominates, making “common-sense utopia” far from mostly-great; challenging that does undermine one important route to “no easy eutopia,” but not the broader fragility/multi-factor and bounded-view arguments, so centrality is moderate-low. It offers a plausible counterfamily of moral views (satisficing/anti-expansionist, or treating expansion as optional/risky) under which “best feasible” wouldn’t be pegged to maximal cosmic expansion, thereby weakening the scale-insensitivity point. However, it only partially refutes because the original essay explicitly considers linear views as a live, plausible class and argues many other mechanisms make eutopia narrow even absent pure scale maximization; also, “best feasible” in the essay is percentile-relative to feasible outcomes, not explicitly “quality not maximal scale,” so the critique leans on a definitional reframing more than an internal refutation. Most claims are reasonable, but it overstates that the essay ‘assumes’ expansion is morally mandatory rather than conditional on certain moral theories, hence less than perfect correctness. The critique is clear, focused, and contains little filler.
title: Morally optional expansion challenges scale-based value assumptions
